awd_titl_txt: Mentoring Psychology Research Experiences through Replication with the Collaborative Replication and Education Project
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by improving undergraduate research training in psychology through the use of direct replication as a learning tool. The project will accomplish this through a series of virtual summer workshops for psychology instructors who will learn how to teach students to conduct research by having students complete their own study from start to finish. The workshop series would introduce instructors to the Collaborative Replication and Education Project (CREP), a group that supports direct replication of published work by encouraging instructors to have students conduct these replication studies in their courses. Replication is a hallmark of good science, and work that supports replication through education is a priority for the National Science Foundation. Additionally, the field benefits from direct replication of published work and students are excellent candidates to carry out direct replication, as demonstrated by recent calls for students to engage in this work for their projects and theses (Quintana, 2021). The proposed workshops will take an existing system for student replications, CREP, and provide instructors time and support in developing teaching materials and preparing their courses to use this approach. 

This series of workshops for undergraduate psychology faculty will be held virtually in Summer 2023 and will be delivered to up to 14 participants. The workshops will introduce CREP and demonstrate how it can be used in the context of courses, and then provide resources to support instructors in teaching students how to write meaningful extension hypotheses related to diversity, equity, inclusion, and access. During the series, the facilitators will meet with instructors individually to assist in tailoring each instructor’s work to their specific institution and students. Participants will contribute to a teaching manual for CREP projects and, following the workshop series, will also be invited to contribute to a manuscript related to this manual and their experiences teaching with CREP. Teaching materials and select workshop recordings will be available for other instructors. This project will therefore not only impact these 14 instructors and their students, but also any other instructor who is interested in adopting these projects in the future. The NSF IUSE: EDU Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through its Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Avila University was awarded a conference grant for $49,891 in 2023 to support a series of workshops for psychology instructors who wanted to mentor undergraduate research through replication studies. Replication (finding the same results in multiple independent labs) is an important facet of the scientific process; this work is critical for ensuring that scientific findings are trustworthy, and for understanding how findings might work differently based on different characteristics of the research. However, replication isn’t performed quite as often as it should be. At the same time, students in psychology programs are often encouraged or even required to do their own research as part of their curriculum. A natural fit to help address the need for replication, then, is it direct student energy toward this big need in the field to independently replicate published studies. This is the purpose of the Collaborative Replication and Education Project (CREP), the organization responsible for curating the NSF-sponsored workshops.

 

The goals of the workshop were to:

  1. Familiarize future instructors with CREP by completing a project together as a mock student group
  2. Assist future CREP users in identifying when and how to incorporate CREP into their classes
  3. Assist existing CREP users in identifying and implementing improvements to their application of CREP in the classroom
  4. Provide instructors with strategies for teaching students how to incorporate extension hypotheses related to diversity, equity, inclusion, and access (DEIA) in their course work
  5. Engage participants in the modification of existing curricular materials and development of new materials to improve the adaptability of CREP in the classroom throughout the curriculum (in both beginning, intermediate, and advanced courses in psychology curricula).

 

 

In Summer 2023, we recruited and then worked with 14 instructors in a series of six meetings (four workshops and two individual meetings) designed to maximize their ability to mentor students in conducting replications of published work. Several participants had experience supervising CREP or other replications, while most participants did not. The four workshop sessions lasted four hours each, and had specific topics:

1.    Introduction. Topics: CREP history, infrastructure, resources, mission, and products. Discussion of lessons learned with instructors who have used CREP. Introduction to currently available studies.

2.    Teaching CREP. Topics: CREP Step-by-Step from the learner's lens - participants will create mock CREP projects in groups. Presentations and discussion around teaching replication and open science. Well-done exemplar OSF pages will be shown and discussed.

3.    Extension Hypotheses and Individualized Student Experiences. Topics: Mentoring extension hypotheses, with an emphasis on extension hypotheses that meaningfully engage students on questions related to diversity, equity, inclusion, and access. CREP alumni will discuss their individualized experiences.

4.    Participant Presentations and Teaching Hackathon. Topics: Participants will present the highlights of the course or assignment(s) they have prepared as a result of the workshop. The rest of the session will engage participants in a "hackathon"-style meeting to develop curricular/teaching materials for CREP.

 

Following the series of workshops, the videos were uploaded to a public YouTube playlist (linked here) and teaching materials produced by participants and facilitators were uploaded to a publicly available page on the Open Science Framework (linked here).

 

What Were the Results?

  1. Workshop participants have mentored 12 student-led replication projects. Of these, five have been completed and processed, showcasing the immediate impact of the training.
  2. One participant, Jacob Miranda, has taken on significant leadership roles within CREP. He became an Executive Reviewer and now serves as the Peer Mentor Director for a related NSF-funded project.
  3. Another participant, Amanda Woodward, conducted a meta-analysis of an earlier CREP project with students. The students are now writing this analysis for publication, further contributing to the field of psychology.
  4. Participants developed materials to help students conduct replication studies and consider equity issues in research. These tools are being refined and will be shared more widely.
  5. By making the workshops available on YouTube, educators worldwide can now access this valuable training.
  6. The third workshop focused on mentoring extension hypotheses to test DEIA-related research questions, and this workshop is now available for any interested instructor.

 

What’s Next?

  • We are writing an article for a teaching-focused journal to share what we’ve learned with even more educators.
  • We will continue supporting educators and students in replication, helping to build a more robust and inclusive foundation for psychological research.

 

Why Does This Matter?

The success of this project can be found both in its impact on individual instructors and their students, as well as lasting, publicly available products. This work can make research more accessible and impactful for educators and students alike, by engaging students in meaningful research during their curriculum.
